Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Story: My phone buzzed with a new email just as I was double-checking the address on the medical supply package. The subject line flashed: “URGENT: Need Confirmation for Partner Meeting.” Leadership needed my reply now, and I knew how important it was to keep communication flowing—especially with external partners. But the hospital was only a few blocks away, and the supplies in my hands were marked “Time Sensitive.” If I delayed, patient care could be compromised. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount. My colleagues expected me to be responsive, to show I was reliable and engaged. At the same time, the hospital staff—and the patients—were counting on me to deliver these supplies without delay. My mind raced, torn between the pinging demands of my inbox and the weight of the package in my arms. I stood frozen on the sidewalk, wrestling with the impossible choice between being the dependable colleague and the responsible delivery person.
